titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mount Vernon Seminary and College records from administrator Nina Mikhalevsky , 1905-2000 MVC0042.RG
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:45:07 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Seminary and College records from administrator Nina Mikhalevsky
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract: This collection contains meeting minutes and administrative files belonging to Dr. Nina Mikhalevsky, a professor and administrator at Mount Vernon College for over 20 years. Mikhalevsky held many positions at Mount Vernon College including chair of the Liberal Studies department, dean of students, and director of the Elizabeth J. Somers Women's Leadership Program, among others. The materials in this collection range in date from 1905-2000, with the bulk of the materials dating from 1980-2000.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: Meeting minutes and Administrative files.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Mount Vernon Seminary and College archives were acquired by GWU upon merger with Mount Vernon College. The collection was transferred to the Foggy Bottom campus in 2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Nina Mikhalevsky joined Mount Vernon College's faculty in 1979 and remained at the college for two decades. She was the first director of the honors program, chair of the Liberal Studies Department, presiding officer of the faculty, dean of students and campus life, director of the Elizabeth J. Somers Women's Leadership Program, and assistant dean of The George Washington University's Columbian College of Arts and Sciences. She is also the author of the book, Dear Daughters: A history of Mount Vernon Seminary and College, which was published in 2001.
Dr. Mikhalevsky holds a Ph.D. (1981) and an M.A. (1977) in philosophy from Georgetown University, as well as a B.A. (1974) in philosophy from Boston University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains meeting minutes and administrative files from the office of Dr. Nina Mikhalevsky, a professor and administrator who held various positions at Mount Vernon College for two decades beginning in 1979. The materials in this collection range in date from 1905-2000, with the bulk of the materials dating from 1980-2000.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains meeting minutes from the Mount Vernon College Board of Trustees, The Council for Mount Vernon, Mount Vernon College faculty, and various Board committees. The materials range in date from 1991-2000.

did.unittitle: The Council for Mount Vernon Fall meeting
The Council for Mount Vernon meeting minutes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains adminiatrative files including event files, programs and pamphlets, and files regarding various groups and committees related to Mount Vernon College. The materials in this series date from 1905-2000, with the bulk of the material dating from 1980-2000.
